Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: As I sat at the dinner table, my family’s laughter filled the room while we tossed around ideas for our weekend together. My younger brother wanted to go hiking, and my parents suggested a movie night. I could see how much it meant to them that I join in—after all, we rarely get time like this anymore. But in the back of my mind, I kept thinking about the free vaccine clinic at the community center this weekend. As a responsible citizen, I felt a strong pull to volunteer, especially since the clinic was short-staffed and the turnout was expected to be high. I had already organized my tax documents, so I knew I could spare the time. Yet, the thought of disappointing my family, who expected me to be present and engaged, made my chest tighten. I wanted to be a good sister, to laugh and make memories, but I also wanted to do my part for the community. The two roles tugged at me from opposite sides, and I sat quietly, torn, as the conversation swirled around me.
